Acid treated montmorillonite was used as a catalyst in Prins reaction of α methylstyrene with paraldehyde giving 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane (Vertacetal). The product of this reaction is a bioactive compound, which can interact with GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) receptors and has fragrant properties. Montmorillonite (used for this reaction as catalyst) was prepared by treatment with hydrochloric, nitric, sulfuric or chloroacetic acid. The influence of acid used for treatment, and other reaction conditions (reaction temperature, solvent, reactant molar ratio, catalyst amount) on the reaction course were tested. Acid treated montmorillonite proved to be a catalyst suitable for this reaction – a high yield of desired product was obtained (>94%) at room temperature using different solvents. Solvent choice showed to be crucial for the reaction – the best results were obtained using nitromethane or 1,4-dioxane. The catalyst can be reused one time after calcination at 300 °C. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane Vertacetal Montmorillonite Acid catalyzed reaction Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Montmorillonite, cheap natural clay material, possesses many properties suitable for catalysis – e. g., large specific surface, and a high ion-exchange capacity. Besides its catalytic application, it can also be used as solid support for active pharmaceutical ingredients [1–4]. From the chemical point of view, it can be described by the formula Al2SiO4(OH)2․nH2O. The crystal structure of montmorillonite consists of several layers. Each contains two SiO2 tetrahedrons, which have between them Al2O3 octahedrons [3]. In the interlayer space, different types of cations (H +, Na+, Mg2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, etc.) are present. Brønsted and Lewis acid sites make this material usable in organic synthesis as heterogeneous acid catalysts. Enhancing the catalytic activity is frequently performed by increasing material acidity by ion exchange of Na+ ions present in the material by protons (H +) – mostly using inorganic acids. Modification with hydrochloric or sulfuric acid accompanied by the enhancement of catalytic acidity of clay materials was described, e. g., in Prins cyclization of isoprenol with isovaleraldehyde [5], Prins cyclization of isoprenol with benzaldehyde [6], hydration of α -pinene to α -terpineol [7] or isomerization of carvone to carvacrol [8]. Sidorenko [5] reported that modification of halloysite with hydrochloric acid led to 50% increase of catalytic activity in Prins reaction of isoprenol with isovaleraldehyde accompanied with significant increase of selectivity to desired tetrahydropyranol products. Vyskočilová [6] described 70% increase of catalytic activity of montmorillonite K10 modified with sulfuric acid in Prins cyclization of isoprenol with benzaldehyde. Sekerová [7] reported 200% increase in catalytic activity in case of montmorillonite K10 modified with hydrochloric or sulfuric acid in α -pinene hydration. In our previous work [8] we described 350% increase in catalytic activity of monmorillonite K10 after modification with hydrochloric, sulfuric or nitric acid accompanied by significant increase of selectivity to desired product in carvone isomerization to carvacrol. 2,4,6-Trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane is a 1,3-dioxane derivative, which can be pre-pared by Prins reaction of α-methylstyrene with acetaldehyde or paraldehyde (Fig. 1 ). Racemic mixture of 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane is a fragrance, commercially available under names Floropal® or Vertacetal® [9]. This fragrance is valued for its fruity-floral-green scent and is used in cosmetics or detergent production. From the point of view of pharmaceutical properties, its interaction with GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) receptors was described recently [10]. Synthesis of 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane was described mainly using Brønsted type catalysts – e.g., in a patent [11], a mixture of formic and sulfuric acid (using paraldehyde) was used as a catalyst. Other described catalysts in the reaction of α-methylstyrene with acetaldehyde were catexes (e.g., SP111, SPC118, Lewatit, Amberlyst 15) [11,12], providing a high yield (75%). Also, iodine in dichloromethane was reported in the reaction of α-methylstyrene with paraldehyde as a catalyst (>88% yield) [9,13]. This work aims to test the catalytic activity of cheap and available montmorillonite in the Prins reaction of α-methylstyrene with paraldehyde, which is rarely reported to our knowledge. The only reference [14] of montmorillonite usage in Prins reaction of α-methylstyrene with paraldehyde is in article dealing with Prins reaction of styrene with paraldehyde using cerium (III) modified montmorillonite, where 61% yield of 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane was obtained after 12 h at 80 °C. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Material synthesis - montmorillonite modification with acids Montmorillonite K10 (10 g, Sigma Aldrich) was mixed with 50 ml of 1 M acid water solution. The suspension was stirred at room temperature (RT) overnight, filtered (filter S4), and washed with demineralized water until the filtrate was neutral. Prepared materials were dried in an oven under air at 100 °C. Acids used for this modification were: hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, sulfuric acid (all Penta, p.a., Praha, Czech Republic), and chloroacetic acid (Sigma Aldrich, >99%, Darmstadt, Germany). 2.2 Catalytic tests 2.2.1 Typical experiment Experiments were performed in a round-bottomed flask. To the flask, catalyst (20 wt.% to α-methylstyrene), 3 ml of solvent, 5 mmol of paraldehyde (Sigma Aldrich, >97%, Darmstadt, Germany), and 5 mmol of α-methylstyrene (Sigma Aldrich, 99%, Darmstadt, Germany) were placed. Most of the reactions were performed at room temperature; when the influence of the temperature was monitored, the desired temperature was used. The flask was stirred by a magnetic stirrer. Analysis of the reaction mixture was performed using a gas chromatograph (VF-5 ms column, FID, Varian CP-3800 chromatograph, Palo Alto, CA, USA), carrier gas was nitrogen, internal standard (mesitylene) was used. Filtration test was used to confirm that reaction is only heterogeneously catalyzed – reaction was carried out using typical reaction conditions (MMT-HCl) for 30 min, then the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture and this mixture was stirred for 24 h. The fact, that the reaction did not take place after catalyst removal confirmed heterogeneity of this reaction. The reaction rate (r) of 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane formation was calculated to compare influence of different reaction conditions on reaction course (n – amount of 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane (TMPD), m – mass, t – time). r = n T M P D [ m o l ] m c a t . [ g ] × t [ m i n ] 2.2.2 Catalyst regeneration Once used catalyst was centrifuged and removed from the reaction mixture. After that, it was washed three times with 1,4-dioxane (>99.5%, Penta, Praha, Czech Republic) and again centrifuged. Finally, the regenerated catalyst was collected and dried in an oven at 100 °C overnight, and when it was necessary, it was also calcined at 300 °C. 2.3 Characterization methods Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of pyridine was performed to compare the acidity of all materials (AutoChem II Micromeritics Instrument 2920, Unterschleissheim, Germany). A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and quadrupole mass spectrometer (MKS Cirrus 2 Analyzer, MKS Instruments, Crewe, UK) with a capillary coupling system were used for the desorbed pyridine detection. A catalyst sample (0.09 g) was placed in a quartz U-shaped tube. Prior to adsorption of pyridine, the catalyst was heated under a helium flow (30 mL/min) up to 100 °C, and kept at 100 °C for 60 min to remove impurities from the sample, and clean the material surface. Measured pulses of pyridine (pulse volume, 5 mL) were injected into the helium gas and carried through the catalyst sample until adsorption saturation. Then, the sample was flushed with helium for 120 min to remove physisorbed pyridine. Afterward, the linear temperature program (10 °C/min) was started at a temperature of 100 °C and the sample was heated up to a temperature of 900 °C. The amount of desorbed pyridine was determined by calibration of the intensity of the 79 amu MS response (5 mL loop) [15–17]. Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) was performed to analyze the amount of carbonaceous deposits on the reused catalysts (Autochem II 2920 Micromeritics, Unterschleissheim, Germany). Both a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a quadrupole mass spectrometer (MKS Cirrus 2 Analyzer, Crewe, UK) with a capillary coupling system were used for CO2 detection (released after oxidation of carbonaceous deposits from the samples). A material sample (0.09 g) was placed in a quartz U-shaped tube. Before the TPO experiment, the catalyst was heated under a helium flow (30 mL/min) up to 80 °C, and kept at 80 °C for 20 min to dry the catalyst. Afterward, a catalyst was set up to O2 He flow (10% O2 in helium, 30 mL/min), the linear temperature program (15 °C/min) started, and the sample was heated up to a temperature of 900 °C. The amount of originated carbon dioxide was determined by calibrating the intensity of the 44 amu MS response (0.5 mL loop)[8]. The specific surface area was measured using nitrogen adsorption (3Flex volumetric analyzer, Micromeritics, Unterschleissheim, Germany) and calculated via the BET equation and t-plot method. DR-UV/Vis measurement was performed using a Shimadzu 2600i (Kyoto, Japan) spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere ISR-2600 Plus. The solid samples were measured on the BaSO4 tablets. The particle size distributions of all samples were determined by laser light scattering (Malvern Mastersizer 3000 system equipped with Hydro EV wet sampling unit, Malvern Instruments Ltd., Cambridge, UK). The materials were characterized using a wet dispersion method. The particle size distributions were recorded for ten determinations for each sample at an obscuration range of 8–14%. The particle size distributions of all materials were determined using demineralized water (conductivity < 1 µS·cm-1) with surfactant Triton X-100 (Aldrich, Darmstadt, Germany) as a dispersion medium. The reference refractive index for all materials was 1.555 [18]. XRF analysis was performed on WD-XRF ARL 9400 XP Spectrometer (Malvern Instruments Ltd., Cambridge, UK). Powders for SEM analysis were applied on carbon adhesive tape and then goldened by 5 nm of gold via Quorum Q150 ES (Quorum Technologies Ltd., Laughton, UK). Footage was made by scanning electron microscope TESCAN Lyra3 GMU/EDS/EBSD/STEM/TOFSIMS (Tescan Brno, Brno, Czech Republic) in regime low vacuum (UniVac) at pressure in working chamber 1 Pa, accelerating voltage 5 kV and using SE detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characterization Results from X-ray fluorescence are summarized in Table 1 . The composition of non-modified montmorillonite K10 (MMT K10) and materials modified with acids remained the same. Morphology of materials was monitored by SEM analysis and it was confirmed that particle size was preserved after modification with acids (Figure S1 in supplementary information). The acidity of materials measured by temperature desorption of pyridine (Fig. 2 , Table 2 ) increased from an initial value of 550 µmolpyr·gcat −1 (non-modified MMT) almost up to 900 µmolpyr·gcat −1 in the case of materials modified with acids. We observed that from the point of view of material acidity, the treatment of material with inorganic acids was more successful compared to chloroacetic acid. Non-modified montmorillonite contained one broad peak with a local maximum of around 200 °C, indicating that more types of acid sites were present in the material. A new type of strong acid site with a maximum of around 520 °C originated after the modification with acids, and a slight decrease in the intensity of weak acid sites was observed. The amount of these newly formed acid sites in-creased in the row MMT-ClCOOH < MMT-H2SO4 < MMT-HCl < MMT-HNO3. Due to the fact that the amount of the weak and middle strong acid sites was almost the same in all cases, these strong acid sites were responsible for the significant increase in acidity of acid-treated MMT. The prevalent acid sites in MMT are the Brønsted acid sites [19]. The Brønsted acid sites in acid-treated MMT are from (i) interlayer H3O+, (ii) protonation of SiO groups in the layers of MMT due to the breakage of Al-O-Si bonds after acid treatment, and (iii) a proton attraction by hydroxyl groups Si-OH and Al-OH in acid environment [20–22]. The unsaturated Al3+ ions present at broken edges of MMT might be the source of Lewis acidity [20]. Nitrogen physisorption was used to compare the textural properties of materials (Fig. 3 , Table 3 , Fig. S5–S9)). All samples showed adsorption isotherms of type IV (IUPAC classification). Samples consisted of only mesopores with classical type hysteresis loop H3 (IU-PAC classification), which corresponded to non-rigid aggregates of plate-like particles (e.g., clays). Total pore volume was 0.34–0.36 cm3/g in all cases. Adsorption isotherms of all modified samples were similar to nonmodified material, meaning that material structure did not change significantly during the modification. Preservation of montmorillonite structure after modification with acids was confirmed by X-ray diffraction in our previous works [7,8] Laser light scattering was used to monitor the particle size distribution of raw and acid-treated montmorillonite (Table 4 , Fig. 4 ). Raw montmorillonite had a little higher Dv(50) value (23.0 µm) than modified materials (10.2–14.4 µm) meaning that it contained slightly bigger particles. Stirring the materials during the treatment was probably responsible for such a change. Dv(10) values, i.e., the boundary value for 10% of the smallest particles, were similar for all materials (3.36–3.76 µm). All materials did not contain bigger particles than approx. 300 µm. Temperature programmed oxidation was used to determine the amount of carbonaceous deposits on fresh and reused materials (Table 5 ). It was detected that a certain amount of carbonaceous deposits was present already in a fresh material, which was in correspondence with already published data for elemental analysis [7,8]. After the reaction, a higher carbonaceous deposits amount was observed as expected. A higher amount was present in the material regenerated by drying at 100 °C compared to regeneration by calcination at 300 °C. Diffuse UV/Vis reflectance (DR-UV/Vis) of physisorbed pyridine was used for the semiquantitative determination of the amount of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites present on the acid modified MMT surface (Fig. 5 ). MMT-ClCOOH differed the most from the other materials. In this material, the band at approx. 38,000 cm−1, which was attributed to Lewis acid sites described by π-π* excitation of pyridine [23] was insignificant. It possessed the broadest band at ca 39,000 cm−1 representing the presence of Brønsted acid sites (π-π* excitation of pyridinium). Due to the shift, it is also possible that the physisorbed pyridine was also present in this material. MMT-H2SO4 showed the most intense band at 44,000 cm−1, which describes Lewis acid sites (charge transfer), and at 27,000 cm−1 showing the presence of Brønsted acid sites given by the presence of isolated hydroxyl groups (Si-OH). The last-mentioned band was present in all materials, as we expected. MMT-HCl possesses the most intense band at 39,000 cm−1 (Brønsted acid sites). To summarize, MMT-HNO3, MMT-H2SO4, and MMT-HCl had both types of acid sites, and MMT-ClCOOH almost only the Brønsted ones. The highest amount of Lewis acid sites was present in MMT-H2SO4. 3.2 Catalytic testing The catalytic activity of prepared materials was tested in the Prins reaction of α-methylstyrene with paraldehyde giving desired product 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane. 3.2.1 Treatment by acids The material was modified using acids (sulfuric, nitric, hydrochloric, and chloroacetic) because it is a common way of montmorillonite acidity enhancement described in the literature [5–8]. The influence of different reaction conditions – a type of modifying acid, temperature, reactant ratio, catalyst amount, and solvent type was tested (Table 6 ). It was also confirmed that no reaction took place without a catalyst. Toluene was chosen as the reaction solvent according to the literature [11] for the first experiments and the comparison of the treatment of MMT by different acids. The reaction course is depicted in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that acid modification definitely led to catalytic activity enhancement. From the point of view of reaction rate, it increased ca. 6 – 9 times after the modification. From further experiments emerged that 1,4-dioxane is a more suitable solvent for this reaction. In dioxane, even nonmodified montmorillonite showed sufficient catalytic activity, and the achieved conversion increased by about 50% (Table 6, rows 1 and 6). The influence of catalyst amount (table 6, rows 19, 24, 25) showed the expected results – with increasing catalyst amount the achieved conversion increased and the selectivity was not influenced. The decreased of the average reaction rate with increasing catalyst amount showed the inaccessibility of some active site (this fact is often observed using higher solid catalyst amount in the reaction mixture). We compared the MMT treated by different acids from the point of view of reaction rate and the obtained selectivity. After evaluating the dependence of reaction rate on the total acidity (Fig. 7 a), it was clear that the reaction rate increased with the material's acidity. However, the difference in the reaction rate between the most acidic materials (MMT-H2SO4, MMT-HCl, and MMT-HNO3) was almost negligible. MMT treated with sulfuric acid was the most active catalyst, even though it had the lowest acidity of all three mentioned materials. However, it contained the highest amount of Lewis acid sites. After checking the dependence of the reaction rate on the amount of the strong acid sites, the same behavior was visible (Fig. 7b). The rate increased with the increasing amount of strong acid sites up to MMT-H2SO4 and then remained almost on the same level. We observed the same trend in the case of the dependence of selectivity in 1 h on both total acidity and amount of strong acid sites (Fig. 7d, 7e). However, the difference was not significant, and we can confirm that it was not important whether Lewis or Brønsted acid sites were present in the catalyst. The lowest selectivity was achieved using pure MMT, followed by MMT-ClCOOH, which both contained predominantly Brønsted acid sites. However, MMT-H2SO4 containing the highest Lewis acid sites was third in the row. The highest selectivity was obtained using MMT-HCl together with MMT-HNO3. The difference between MMT-HNO3 was in the range of measurement error comparing MMT-H2SO4. In our previous work, [7], we found the significant influence of the strength of the acid used for the treatment on the reaction course. The strength of the acid (described by pKa) might influence the properties of the treated material. From the dependence of reaction rate on the pKa of the used acid (Fig. 7c, Table S1 in supplementary information), the increasing pKa led to an increase in the reaction rate. However, except for hydrochloric acid, which has the highest pKa, the rate was not the highest. The same was the dependence of the selectivity in 1 h on pKa (Fig. 7f). In this case, the exception was nitric acid. Still, as it was mentioned above, the difference in selectivity was almost negligible in the case of using more acidic materials. 3.2.2 Influence of reaction solvent The influence of solvent was tested using many solvents, but only a few were suitable for the studied reaction (Table 6, rows 2,7–18, Figure S3). In general, reaction occurred (with insight into formation of desired product, >70 rel.%, 24 h) the best in nonpolar, little basic solvents (toluene, heptane, cyclohexane), and also in 1,4-dioxane, ethyl acetate, and nitromethane. The best result was obtained in nitromethane – after 2 h of reaction, 98% of desired product was present in the reaction mixture. A high selectivity toward desired product was also observed in ethyl acetate (99 rel.%, 24 h). When comparing toluene and 1,4-dioxane, toluene provided slightly better conversion (99 to 94%, 6 h), but in the case of 1,4-dioxane, a higher selectivity to the desired product was obtained (94 vs. 87%, 6 h). Cyclohexane also provided a high selectivity to the desired product (95%, 6 h), but the conversion was significantly lower (60%, 6 h). The reaction did not proceed using butan-2-one, propan-2-ol, tetrahydrofurane, and acetonitrile, probably due to their high polarity (relative permittivity 18–38, in the case of butan-2-one, propan-2-ol, and acetonitrile), or the combination of polarity and basicity (tetrahydrofurane). The polar solvents would interact strongly with the hydrophilic MMT compared to less polar reactants. In polar solvents (dimethylsulfoxide, N,N’-dimethylformamide), which were able to stabilize carbocations, only low conversions were obtained (<25%, 24 h) due to their strong basicity blocking the acids sites active for catalysis. In the case of dichloromethane, the reaction rate was high, but the desired product was not detected in the reaction mixture. Only dimerization of α-methylstyrene took place. The products identified following the literature [24,25] are depicted in Fig. 8 a, b. Chosen solvent properties are summarized in Table 7 – donor number (DN) represents ability of solvent to solvate cations and Lewis acids, dielectric constant (ε) describes the solvent polarity and pKa describes the ability of solvent to stabilize anions (thus represents the acidity). The basicity was also a critical parameter in solvents, which were somehow usable for the studied reaction (the conversion after 1 h at least 20%). The evaluation was impossible in the case of the solvents that do not possess any basicity (DN = 0). On the other side, using the solvents with measurable basicity, the clear observance confirmed that the rate of acid catalyzed reaction significantly decreased with the increasing donor number of the solvent (Fig. 9 a). The basicity of the solvent did not influence the achieved selectivity. We supposed that the acidity of the solvent might have a positive effect on the reaction rate. However, the results showed no such trend (Fig. 9a). The influence of reaction rate on pKa (Fig. 9c) seemed to be divided into two parts: the reaction rate increased with the increasing acidity (pKa). The reaction rate decreased in the row cyclohexane > ethyl acetate > 1,4-dioxane, and the second row decreased from toluene to nitromethane. So, it means that the pKa of the chosen solvents influenced neither the reaction rate nor the selectivity. We also took into consideration the polarity of the solvent (Fig. 9b). The solvents toluene, 1,4-dioxane, heptane, and cyclohexane had almost the same polarity, so for the comparison, one of them, cyclohexane, was chosen, and it was compared with ethyl acetate and nitromethane (Fig. 9b). The figure showed that with increasing polarity the reaction rate increased. Still, it is necessary to consider the abovementioned fact that the combination of high polarity and high basicity was negative for the reaction proceeding. Thus, the optimal choice of solvent was a complex problem. Moreover, many other factors might play a role in a liquid phase reaction, and we have chosen only the most significant from our point of view. 3.2.3 Influence of reaction temperature To determine temperature influence on the reaction course (Fig. 10 ), 1,4-dioxane was chosen as a reaction solvent. The increased reaction temperature increased the reaction rate, as expected. We calculated the apparent activation energy based on the linearized form of the Arrhenius equation, which was 10.1 kJ/mol. This value might be comparable with the results from the literature [30]. High conversion and selectivity to the desired product (>90%, 6 h) were observed using room temperature, 40 and 60 °C. Using 80 °C, a total conversion was obtained after 1 h of reaction. However, the selectivity to the desired product was significantly lower (67%, 1 h), and it decreased with the increasing time due to the formation of undesired products. It was observed that using the temperature of 80 °C, mainly dimerization of α-methylstyrene took place (Fig. 8a,b). 3.2.4 Possibility of catalyst reuse The possibility of catalyst reuse was tested using two ways of catalyst regeneration – drying at 100 °C or calcination at 300 °C (Fig. 11 , data in Table 6 rows 19,26,27, regeneration process described in chapter 2.2.2). At first reuse, a decrease in catalytic activity was observed. With regard to selectivity, no difference was observed when using fresh or regenerated catalysts. On the contrary, a significant decrease in reaction rate was observed after regeneration. Increased carbonaceous deposits can explain the decrease in the reaction rate of materials after regeneration (Table 5). 2nd reuse was also performed. However, no catalytic activity was observed regardless of regeneration type – we expected that the further increase of carbonaceous de-posits caused this decrease in activity. The calcination at 300 °C was more efficient from the point of view of removing the carbonaceous deposits comparing drying. Still, such a temperature was insufficient for the total regeneration of materials, and a higher temperature should be used. TGA curves of the spent catalyst showed (Figure S2 in supplementary information) that the temperature necessary for removing all carbonaceous deposits after the reaction should be higher than 550 °C. However, this temperature would destroy the Brønsted acid sites in the material. 3.2.5 Proposed reaction mechanism From the obtained results and information available in the literature, we offered a reaction scheme as follows (Fig. 12 ): free electron pairs of oxygen in paraldehyde interact with acid sites (AS), causing the generation of protonated aldehyde molecule (I), which is in equilibrium with its corresponding cation (II). This carbocation from acetaldehyde reacts with a double bond at α-methylstyrene (III), creating carbocation intermediate (IV), which reacts with another acetaldehyde carbocation, creating desired 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane (V). 3.2.6 Comparison with data in literature This reaction is not often described in the literature (Table 8 ). From results reported for the heterogeneous catalysts, our materials provided the highest yield, adding the possibility of simple catalyst removal from the reaction mixture. 4 Conclusions In this work, we presented a novel usage of acid-modified montmorillonite as a catalyst in the Prins reaction of α-methylstyrene and paraldehyde, which was not yet reported. Several types of acid modified montmorillonite were prepared and characterized in detail. Material composition and structure were characterized using X-Ray fluorescence and diffraction. Enhancement of material acidity with modification was confirmed by temperature-programmed desorption (from 550 to 679–895 µmolpyr·gcat −1). The specific surface area of modified materials was almost the same as that of nonmodified materials. The comparison of the type of the acid sites was performed by DR-UV/Vis. The catalytic activity of prepared materials in the Prins reaction of α-methylstyrene with paraldehyde was confirmed. Montmorillonite modification with acids positively influenced the reaction course, and a high yield of the desired 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane was obtained - 95% (MMT-HCl, nitromethane, RT, 1 h) and 94% (MMT-H2SO4, 1,4-dioxane, 40 °C, 6 h). This was caused by the increased acidity of prepared materials. A detailed study of the solvent influence on the reaction course was also offered – the solvents suitable for reaction were non polar and low basic (toluene, cyclohexane, heptane) or polar and non-basic (1,4-dioxane, ethyl acetate and nitromethane), other tested solvents provided either very low conversions or unsatisfactory selectivity to desired product. This showed the necessity of the correct solvent choice – in this case, the best was polar and nonbasic nitromethane followed by nonpolar midbasic 1,4-dioxane. Catalysts can be reused once after calcination at 300 °C with only a slight activity decrease (24 h). The yield of the desired product was higher than the present in the literature using heterogeneous catalysts. To summarize the obtained results: the most suitable catalyst for this reaction showed to be MMT-H2SO4 and MMT-HCl providing similar results, the best results were obtained using nitromethane, but 1,4-dioxane provided also similar results and can be preferred because of its availability. Moreover, the availability of MMT material makes this way of Prins reaction very promising. coredata.dc:description: Acid treated montmorillonite was used as a catalyst in Prins reaction of α methylstyrene with paraldehyde giving 2,4,6-trimethyl-4-phenyl-1,3-dioxane (Vertacetal). The product of this reaction is a bioactive compound, which can interact with GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) receptors and has fragrant properties. Montmorillonite (used for this reaction as catalyst) was prepared by treatment with hydrochloric, nitric, sulfuric or chloroacetic acid. The influence of acid used for treatment, and other reaction conditions (reaction temperature, solvent, reactant molar ratio, catalyst amount) on the reaction course were tested. Acid treated montmorillonite proved to be a catalyst suitable for this reaction – a high yield of desired product was obtained (>94%) at room temperature using different solvents. Solvent choice showed to be crucial for the reaction – the best results were obtained using nitromethane or 1,4-dioxane. The catalyst can be reused one time after calcination at 300 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Acid treated montmorillonite - efficient catalyst in Prins reaction of alpha-methylstyrene with paraldehyde
